core: 1 Know that waves transfer energy without transferring matter [2].
2 Describe what is meant by wave motion as illustrated by vibrations in ropes and springs, and by experiments using water waves [2].
3 Describe the features of a wave in terms of wavefront, wavelength, frequency, crest (peak), trough, amplitude and wave speed [3].
4 Recall and use the equation for wave speed v = fλ [3].

5 Know that for a transverse wave, the direction of vibration is at right angles to the direction of propagation and understand that electromagnetic radiation, water waves and seismic S-waves (secondary) can be modelled as transverse [3].

6 Know that for a longitudinal wave, the direction of vibration is parallel to the direction of propagation and understand that sound waves and seismic P-waves (primary) can be modelled as longitudinal [3].
7 Describe how waves can undergo reflection at a plane surface, refraction due to a change of speed, and diffraction through a narrow gap [4].
8 Describe the use of a ripple tank to show reflection at a plane surface, refraction due to depth change, and diffraction due to a gap or an edge [4].
supplement: 9 Describe how wavelength and gap size affects diffraction through a gap [4].
10 Describe how wavelength affects diffraction at an edge [4].

core: 1 Define and use the terms normal, angle of incidence and angle of reflection [5].
2 Describe the formation of an optical image by a plane mirror and give its characteristics (same size, same distance, virtual) [5].
3 State that for reflection, the angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection; recall and use this relationship [5].
supplement: 4 Use simple constructions, measurements and calculations for reflection by plane mirrors [5].

core: 1 Define and use the terms normal, angle of incidence and angle of refraction [6].
2 Describe an experiment to show refraction of light by transparent blocks of different shapes [6].
3 Describe the passage of light through a transparent material [6].
4 State the meaning of critical angle [6].
5 Describe internal reflection and total internal reflection using both experimental and everyday examples [6].
supplement: 6 Define refractive index, n, as the ratio of the speeds of a wave in two different regions [6].
7 Recall and use the equation n = sin i / sin r [7].
8 Recall and use the equation n = 1 / sin c [7].
9 Describe the use of optical fibres, particularly in telecommunications [7].

core: 1 Describe the action of thin converging and thin diverging lenses on a parallel beam of light [7].
2 Define and use the terms focal length, principal axis and principal focus [7].
3 Draw and use ray diagrams for the formation of a real image by a converging lens [7].
4 Describe the characteristics of an image using terms such as enlarged/diminished, upright/inverted and real/virtual [7].
5 Know that a virtual image is formed when diverging rays are extrapolated backwards and does not form a visible projection on a screen [8].
supplement: 6 Draw and use ray diagrams for the formation of a virtual image by a converging lens [8].
7 Describe the use of a single lens as a magnifying glass [8].
8 Describe the use of converging and diverging lenses to correct long-sightedness and short-sightedness [8].

core: 1 Describe the dispersion of light as illustrated by the refraction of white light by a glass prism [8].
2 Know the traditional seven colours of the visible spectrum in order of frequency and wavelength [9].
supplement: 3 Recall that visible light of a single frequency is described as monochromatic [9].

core: 1 Know the main regions of the electromagnetic spectrum in order of frequency and wavelength [9].
2 Know that all electromagnetic waves travel at the same high speed in a vacuum [9].
3 Describe typical uses of radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays [10, 11].
4 Describe the harmful effects of excessive exposure to electromagnetic radiation, such as internal heating, skin burns, and mutation [11].
5 Know that communication with artificial satellites is mainly by microwaves [12].
supplement: 6 Know that the speed of electromagnetic waves in a vacuum is 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s [11].
7 Know that mobile phones, Bluetooth, and optical fibres rely on electromagnetic radiation for communication [12, 13].
8 Know the difference between a digital and analogue signal [13].
9 Know that sound can be transmitted as a digital or analogue signal [13].
10 Explain the benefits of digital signalling, including increased transmission rate and range [13].

core: 1 Describe the production of sound by vibrating sources [14].
2 Describe the longitudinal nature of sound waves [14].
3 State the approximate range of frequencies audible to humans as 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz [14].
4 Know that a medium is needed to transmit sound waves [14].
5 Know that the speed of sound in air is approximately 330–350 m/s [14].
6 Describe a method for determining the speed of sound in air [15].
7 Describe how changes in amplitude and frequency affect loudness and pitch [15].
8 Describe an echo as the reflection of sound waves [15].
9 Define ultrasound as sound with a frequency higher than 20 kHz [15].
supplement: 11 Know that sound travels faster in solids than in liquids and faster in liquids than in gases [14].
12 Describe the uses of ultrasound in non-destructive testing, medical scanning, and sonar [15].
